name: MAN.3 Project Management

main_description.name: Objective
main_description.data: The objective of this process is to identify, establish and control the project activities and required resources for the successful execution of the project or the product development.
main_description.bestPractices: The objective described is according to ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017. It is sufficient to achieve the required maturity up to ASPICE Level 3. Use the below table to extend the objective of the process if necessary.

main_description.name: Activity Diagram
main_description.data: The activity diagram of the process MAN.3 Project Management is as shown below:

main_description.name: Activities
main_description.data: The following activities are performed in the scope of the process MAN.3 Project Management:

subitem.name: Scope of the project and timeline
subitem.data:
The project shall be described so that the scope of work is documented in terms of goal, content, motivation, boundaries, and constraints of the project. The responsibilities of the affected party shall be documented for example system development, software development, software testing, etc.

The project timeline shall be defined based on the scope, context, and complexity of the project. The project timeline shall be consistent with the customer timeline and this shall be visible in the project plan.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Be specific in defining the scope of the project. Clearly describe what is not in your scope!
  2. It is not necessary to write down all the information. If the relevant information is available in any of the project documents, provide the reference to the document/section.
  3. If the scope of the project changes during the project, make sure to update the section accordingly.
  4. The work done during the quotation phase includes defining scope, timeline,
subitem.tailoringExample:
The objective of MyCompany is to deliver quality software to MyTier1 within the given budget and timeline. This project may contribute significantly to the revenue of MyCompany and successful execution may lead to similar new projects from the other customers.

In the scope of this project, MyCompany is responsible for the development of the AUTOSAR compliant software as per ASPICE Level 3 and ISO 26262 ASIL B. MyTier1 is responsible for the development at the system level and MyOEM is responsible at the vehicle level. My SupplierA is responsible for the delivery of the AUTOSAR Basic Software (BSW) Stack and MySupplierB is responsible for the delivery of the Microcontroller Abstraction Layer (MCAL) stack. Automotive cybersecurity (ISO 21434) is out of scope.

The project timeline consistent with the MyTier1 timeline and MyOEM timeline is available in the project plan available here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Feasibility study
subitem.data: A feasibility study has to be conducted to evaluate if the project can be successfully executed considering the technical feasibility concerning time, budget, and resources. The feasibility study shall document the factors considered along with the identified risks and the mitigation action. The mitigation actions shall be planned and tracked to closure during the execution of the project.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. The feasibility study is performed during the contract phase before the start of the project.
  2. Record all the risks identified during the feasibility study using Risk Management tickets in Jira, and monitor and track these risks to closure with suitable mitigation actions.
  3. A committee consisting of relevant experts can be formed to perform the feasibility study
subitem.tailoringExample: A feasibility study has been conducted to evaluate the technical feasibility of the project considering time, budget, and resources. The report can be found here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Project activities
subitem.data:
The execution of the project activities shall be planned so that several, manageable work packages shall be defined with a reasonable outcome. The defined work packages shall enable adequate project progress monitoring and shall be defined based on the timeline and estimation of the project

The work packages shall contain the activities related to engineering, management, and supporting processes. The work packages shall be described in detail to include the dependencies between the activities, required input, and output work products for each of the activities.

Agile methodologies such as Scrum, Kanban, etc. can be used for the monitoring and adjustment of the project activities. At any point in time, detailed (task level) planning for the next two releases shall be available.

A sufficient number of change requests, problems, and verification issues shall be expected to be handled during the project execution. The project schedule shall be defined, keeping in mind the required time and effort to accommodate such requests. Also, the vacation of team members and the planning buffer shall be considered while planning the project activities.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. High-level (functionality level) planning shall be available for the complete project and detailed (task level) planning of activities shall be available for at least the next two releases.
  2. Any delays in the timeline or canceling of functionalities without the agreement with the stakeholders may lead to downrating during the ASPICE assessment.
  3. A buffer time can be included in each sprint and work package to enable the project teams to handle unplanned change requests, problems, and verification issues during the project execution.
subitem.tailoringExample:
The project activities are planned in manageable sizes of work packages and recorded in the project plan available here: PasteLinkHere

The monitoring and adjustment of the project activities are performed according to Scrum methodology.

subitem.name: Estimates, and resources
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. The used estimation method shall be explicitly mentioned.
  2. Resources shall also be planned for the project management activities along with allocation and monitoring to ensure the successful execution of project management activities.
subitem.tailoringExample:
The estimation method NameOfEstimationMethod is used. The detailed project estimation can be found here: PasteLinkHere

The list of tools, licenses and hardware resources used in the project are available in the tool list placed here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Skills, knowledge, and experience
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Identify the required skills to execute the project and rate each of the team members for their level of expertise in these skills
  2. Not all skills are mandatory for all team members. For example, programming skills could be optional for a project manager or quality manager.
subitem.tailoringExample: The skill matrix of the project team including the training plan is available here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Project schedules, interfaces, and agreed commitments
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. The critical path in the project can be identified using the dependencies between the activities. This can be tracked in the project plan and Jira project by linking the dependent activities.
  2. Remember to plan all the project-related meetings along with the project management activities in the project plan.
  3. The work packages have to be formed adequately based on the size and complexity of the project.
  4. If there are various levels of project management involved such as system, software, hardware, etc., then the schedules of different levels shall be linked to provide a clear view of project execution.
  5. The degree of fulfillment of activities can be tracked using both or either both ways. One way is to measure results against the time and duration which is to measure the actual results in the given time and duration and the other is to measure the capacity against the costing position which is to measure the booked effort to the planned effort
subitem.tailoringExample:
The project activities including the engineering, management, and supporting processes recorded in the project plan available here: PasteLinkHere

The monitoring and adjustment of the project activities are done weekly during the sprint planning meeting. Daily standup meetings are utilized to adjust the project activities during the sprint.

All the project interfaces including the customer, supplier, other business units, etc. along with the communication-related activities are recorded and maintained in the project communication and interface matrix available here: PasteLinkHere

All the open topics are recorded and monitored using the project open points list available here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Review, report, and ensure consistency
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices: 1. The consistency between the various project management artifacts is important. For example, the work packages identified during the project estimation shall match the work packages defined in the project schedule
subitem.tailoringExample:
The project status report shared with the customers on weekly basis can be found here: PasteLinkHere

The project status report shared with the management on monthly basis can be found here: PasteLinkHere

The review findings are tracked and monitored to closure using the Jira tickets. These tickets can be identified by filtering Ticket Type = Review and Component = Project Management in the Jira project NameOfYourJiraProject

All the project management review protocols are available here: PasteLinkHere

The organizational lessons learned database is available here:PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Risk Management
subitem.data:
The project risks shall be identified and monitored and corrective actions are taken to mitigate the risk. The risk sources can vary such as budget, timeline, resources, etc. The risk management lifecycle is as shown below:

Initial stateTransitioned stateTransition rationale
Not availableOpenThe risk is identified in the project and recorded in the risk management system.
OpenAnalysisThe risk analysis is initiated.
AnalysisRejectedAnalysis results showed that identified risk is not valid. No risk treatment measures are required.
AnalysisMonitorRisk treatment is initiated based on the treatment actions of actions identified during the risk analysis.
MonitorCorrective actionWhen risk mitigation is not achieved, take corrective actions to reduce or avoid the identified risk.
MonitorClosedThe risk mitigation is successful.
Corrective actionClosedThe risk mitigation through corrective action is successful.

The following are the phases of the risk management lifecycle:
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Always record the risks soon after the identification.
  2. Continue to monitor the risks to avoid any negative impact on the project until it's mitigated or in the case when the project decides not to mitigate the risk
  3. The risk treatment actions and the corrective action shall be practical (implementable) and effective rather than just theoretical.
subitem.tailoringExample:
All the identified risks in the project are monitored and tracked to closure using the ticket type Risk Management in Jira.

The following criteria are applied for the various risk severity levels:

Major : High priority, shall be mitigated within 2 weeks. A valid justification has to be documented if the project team decides not to mitigate the risk.

Medium : : Medium priority, mitigated within 4 weeks. A valid justification has to be documented if the project team decides not to mitigate the risk.

Minor : Low priority, Mitigated within 8 weeks. A valid justification has to be documented if the project team decides not to mitigate the risk.

subitem.name: Agree and Communicate
subitem.data: The work products shall be made available to all the relevant parties. Any update to the work products shall also be communicated to all the relevant parties promptly.
subitem.bestPractices: 1. Describe how this communication is handled in your organization e.g. Using emails, Jira tickets, Configuration item list, etc.
subitem.tailoringExample:
All the updated project management work products are communicated to the relevant interfaces via internal release emails. The internal release email is triggered by the Configuration Manager which shall contain at a minimum, the following information:

  1. Work product name
  2. Release version
  3. Release date
  4. Work product storage path

main_description.name: Roles, Responsibilities, and Authorities
main_description.data:
The participating roles, responsibilities, and authority are described as shown below:

Role Name

Responsibilities,Requirements, Authorities

Project Manager

Responsibilities Planning, support, and control of offer and series projects Responsibility for compliance with cost,quality, deadline, specifications Contact person for feasibility, profitability, and project risk during the inquiry phase Responsible for all technical and administrative tasks Support and implementation of technical change management Requirements Bachelor‘s in engineering, science, or business administration 5+ years experience in automotive (or similar industry) Fluent in English (Mandatory) Outstanding communication, coordination, and organization skills Good PC knowledge, incl. PowerPoint, MS Word, and ExcelExperience with Automotive SPICE Authorities Escalation of resource, budget, and timeline-related risks to management Withhold or delay the release if the release criteria are not met Allocate budget and resources for the project activities Has access rights to the entire project directory

Software Requirement Engineer

Responsibilities Identification, analysis, and evaluation of requirements based on system and customer specifications Understand, consolidate and detail new requirements and acceptance criteria from our internal and external customers and represent them to our software development teams Creationof deviation lists in coordination with the responsible departments Monitoring of compliance withquality rules for the requirements according to ASPICE Requirements Studies in electrical engineering, computer science mechatronics, or a comparable subject Experience in writing software requirements Familiar with a common lifecycle management tool (e.g. Siemens Polarion, Atlassian Jira) Knowledge of the requirements management software IBM DOORS Experience with Automotive SPICE Fluent in English (Mandatory) Authorities No authorities

Software Architect

Responsibilities Define software components,relations between them, external interfaces, and dynamic behavior Analyze customer requirements, derive software architecture requirements, and ensure their traceability in the architectural design Ensure that architectural design can be validated by the software integration test Support the project team regarding the efficiency, quality, and maintainability of the software Discuss software architecture topics with the customer Work in an agile environment Requirements Several years of technical experience in complex embedded systems, preferably in embedded automotive systems Proven track record as Software Architect (m/f/d) Good understanding of the impact of design decisions on quality, reliability, and performance Familiar with software development processes and the V-model Familiar with agile methods such as Scrum or Kanban Autonomous, proactive, team-oriented, and self-reliant way of working combined with a structured and precise working style You are fluent in English Authorities No authorities

Software Developer

Responsibilities Design software unit design and implement the unit design requirements in software Ensure that the unit design can be validated by the software unit test Support the project team regarding the efficiency, quality, and maintainability of the software Discuss software development topics with the customer Work in an open agile working environment and cooperate closely with other team members like hardware developers, architects, and testers Requirements University degree in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, or a related field of study Practical experience in distributed function development Advanced experience in SW development (C/C++, MATLAB/Simulink, QT, CGI Studio) Experience in automotive bus systems A background in the automotive industry is a plus High communication and teamwork skills Familiar with software development processes and the V-model Familiar with agile methods such as Scrum or Kanban You are fluent in English Authorities No authorities

Software Unit Tester

Responsibilities Design of test cases and execution of manual and automated software unit tests in C/C++ Analysis of software unit requirements documents Specifying test cases based on the software unit design in DOORS Evaluation of the test cases with tools such as Tessy. Requirements University degree in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, or a related field of study Ideally ISTQB certificate and initial experience in software unit testing A background in the automotive industry is a plus High communication and teamwork skills Familiar with software development processes and the V-model Familiar with agile methods such as Scrum or Kanban You are fluent in English Authorities No authorities

Software Integrator

Responsibilities Design of test cases and execution of manual and automated software unit tests in C/C++ Analysis of software unit requirements documents Specifying test cases based on the software unit design in DOORS Evaluation of the test cases with tools such as Tessy. Requirements University degree in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, or a related field of study Ideally ISTQB certificate and initial experience in software unit testing A background in the automotiveindustry is a plus High communication and teamwork skills Familiar with software development processes and the V-model Familiar with agile methods such as Scrum or Kanban You are fluent in English Authorities No authorities

main_description.name: Tailoring Guidelines
main_description.data: 1. Any section in this process can be tailored to add project-specific information or exclude any information which is out of scope.
main_description.bestPractices: 1. There are no limits on the budget, volume, team size, documentation, etc. Organizations can set their tailoring guidelines based on what may vary between different types of projects.

not_in_scope: Page is not found in bad request

main_description.name: Objective
main_description.data: The objective of this process is to ensure the integrity of the project and process work products and to ensure their availability to all the relevant stakeholders.
main_description.bestPractices: The objective described is according to ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017. It is sufficient to achieve the required maturity up to ASPICE Level 3. Use the below table to extend the objective of the process if necessary.

main_description.name: Activity Diagram
main_description.data: The activity diagram of the process SUP.8 Configuration Management is as shown below:

main_description.name: Activities
main_description.data: The following activities are performed in the scope of the process SUP.8 Configuration Management:

subitem.name: Define the configuration management strategy
subitem.data:
The configuration management strategy is created so that it shall include the work products used and created in the scope of the project from various disciplines such as system, software, electronic, etc., development locations, and process areas such as engineering, management, and supporting processes. At a minimum following aspects shall be considered:

  • If the different solutions or variants are planned for different disciplines, locations, or processes then an overall strategy shall be defined.
  • The definition of tools and repositories
  • The definition of tools and repositories
  • The definition of the access rights
  • The definition of tools and repositories
  • The identification of configuration items and naming conventions
  • A guideline to create the revision of configuration item
  • Criteria for creation and maintenance of baselines
  • Branching and merging strategy
All the relevant configuration items shall be identified and documented in the Configuration Item List.
subitem.bestPractices: 1. Please keep the above section unchanged as it covers all the required aspects as per ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017.
subitem.tailoringExample: None

main_description.name: Access rights
main_description.data:
The access rights are defined to restrict access to the project information to relevant parties. The following access rights privileges are defined in the project:

Information TypeAccess rightsOwner
Project repositoryProject teamConfiguration manager
JiraProject teamConfiguration manager
ConfluenceProject teamConfiguration manager
DoorsProject teamConfiguration manager
Source codeProject teamConfiguration manager
BackupsProject manager Configuration managerIT manager
main_description.bestPractices: Any other types of access rights used in the project can be described in the project-specific tailoring section.

main_description.name: Backups
main_description.data:
All the configuration items shall be backed up during and after the execution of the project. The IT Manager is responsible to initiate, maintain and troubleshoot any problems in the backups. Following rules shall apply:

Till End of Production:
Configuration Item TypeBackup FrequencyMinimum Number of Backup Instances
Project repository including source codeWeekly10
Doors (All Configuration Items stored in Doors)Weekly10
Jira, ConfluenceDaily30
EmailsWeekly30
All other configuration items which can be backed up (Other than hardware and mechanical components)Weekly10

After the end of production:
A single instance of all the configuration items shall be backed up for at least 15 years.
main_description.bestPractices: Any other backups which are not listed above can be described in the tailoring section.

main_description.name: Objective
main_description.data: The objective of this process is to analyze the System Requirements and System Architecture and to derive the related Software Requirements.
main_description.bestPractices: The objective described is according to ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017. It is sufficient to achieve the required maturity up to ASPICE Level 3. Use the below table to extend the objective of the process if necessary.

main_description.name: Activity Diagram
main_description.data: The activity diagram of the process SWE.1 Software Requirements Analysis is as shown below:

main_description.name: Activities
main_description.data: The following activities are performed in the scope of the process SWE.1 Software Requirements Analysis

subitem.name: Derivation of Software Requirements
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Considering that the functional contents are added over releases, the software requirements shall be iteratively updated.
  2. If the software is not functional safety or cybersecurity relevant, then such topics can be tailored to be out of scope.
  3. The tool to derive and store the software requirements can be changed based on customer requirements.
  4. It is not mandatory to derive the software requirements from the system requirements. If the software is developed as reusable generic software, the platform requirements can be used
  5. Use the SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound) principle while deriving the software requirements.
subitem.tailoringExample:
• The Software Requirements Specification is stored here: Link
  • As the software is non-safety critical, functional safety-related requirements are considered out of scope.
  • The software requirements are derived and stored in the tool DOORS.

subitem.name: Structure and Analysis of Software Requirements
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices: 1. Insufficient memory or other resources in the controller during the project may indicate inappropriate analysis. Make sure that the impact on the operating environment such as microcontroller resources including memory, processor time, and peripheral resources are well studied and documented at the start of the project.
subitem.tailoringExample: The analysis results of the software requirements are recorded in the Software Requirements Review & Analysis Protocol placed here: Link

subitem.data:
A detailed process will be added here.

Requirement TypeVerification Type
Functional“Software Qualification Test” or “Review”
Non-FunctionalReview
subitem.bestPractices: 1. The verification criteria are described during the creation of software requirements.

main_description.name: Objective
main_description.data: The objective of this process is to ensure that the work products and processes comply with the predefined plan and criteria and that further non-conformances are resolved and further prevented.
main_description.bestPractices: The objective described is according to ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017. It is sufficient to achieve the required maturity up to ASPICE Level 3. Use the below table to extend the objective of the process if necessary.

main_description.name: Activity Diagram
main_description.data: The activity diagram of the process SUP.1 Quality Assurance is as shown below:

main_description.name: Activities
main_description.data: The following activities are performed in the scope of the process SUP.1 Quality Assurance:

subitem.name: Quality assurance strategy
subitem.data:
The quality assurance strategy is defined to ensure the independent and objective quality assurances of the work products and processes at the project level without any conflict of interest. The independence can be financial or by the organizational structure. It means the quality assurance manager or engineer shall be independent of the project team and have sufficient authority to bind the project to adhere to the quality processes including escalation to the management when necessary. The quality assurance of the deliveries from the supplier shall also be described in the strategy.

The quality assurance is described based on the following:
  • Automotive SPICE, Version 3.1
  • Automotive SPICE Guidelines, 1st edition, September 2017

    • In addition based on the project requirements, the following can be considered:

  • Customer Requirements

level.name: Review methods
level.data: A detailed process will be added here.
level.tailoringExample: The project quality review report is available here: PasteLinkHere
level.bestPractices:
1. The quality work products shall also need to undergo a quality review.
  2. It is not mandatory that all the project work products undergo a quality review. It can be explicitly stated which review methods apply for which work product
  3. To maintain sufficient independence, if a quality engineer produces quality work products then the quality manager may perform a quality review on the quality work products. If there is only a quality manager in the project responsible to produce the quality work products then the project manager may perform the quality review of quality work products.

subitem.bestPractices: 1. Check on the additional quality guidelines required by the customer and other stakeholders. List them above
subitem.tailoringExample:
In the scope of the project, compliance with the following standard is considered:

  • KGAS v3.5

  2. The internal and external ASPICE assessments are planned and monitored in the project plan available here: PasteLinkHere

level.bestPractices: 1. Plan the internal and external assessment in the project plan. Allocate time and resources to complete the assessments.

subitem.name: Resolution of non-conformances
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.

subitem.name: Escalation mechanism
subitem.data:
The escalation mechanism has to be established according to the quality assurance strategy so that it should cover all the relevant stakeholders including technical, quality, management, customer, etc. After the escalation, the stakeholders shall run the corrective actions.

As depicted in the escalation mechanism, a separate escalation path is defined through the quality team and quality manager. A sufficient level of independence is maintained to ensure the objectivity and effectiveness of the escalation process.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. The used estimation method shall be explicitly mentioned.
  2. Resources shall also be planned for the project management activities along with allocation and monitoring to ensure the successful execution of project management activities.
  3. A committee consisting of relevant experts can be formed to perform the estimation based on the chosen estimation method.
subitem.tailoringExample:
The estimation method NameOfEstimationMethod is used. The detailed project estimation can be found here: PasteLinkHere
The list of tools, licenses and hardware resources used in the project are available in the tool list placed here: PasteLinkHere

subitem.name: Summarize and communicate
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices: Describe how this communication is handled in your organization e.g. Using emails, Jira tickets, Configuration item list, etc.
subitem.tailoringExample:
The monthly quality report to the management is placed here: PasteLinkHere

The quality report to the customer is shared every month placed here: PasteLinkHere

All the updated quality management work products are communicated to the relevant interfaces via internal release emails. The internal release email is triggered by the Configuration Manager which shall contain at a minimum, the following information
  1. Work product name
  2. Release version
  3. Release date
  4. Work product storage path

main_description.data:
The following roles participate in the performance of the activities in this process:

  • Quality Assurance Manager (Responsible)
  • Project Manager (Accountable)
  • Configuration Manager (Supporting)
  • Problem Resolution Manager (Supporting)
  • Change Manager (Supporting)
  • Supplier Manager (Supporting)
  • Software Requirement Engineer (Supporting)
  • Software Architect (Supporting)
  • Software Developer (Supporting)
  • Software Integrator (Supporting)

  • Software Integration Tester (Supporting)
  • Software Qualification Tester (Supporting)
  • System Requirement Engineer (Supporting)
  • System Architect (Supporting)
  • System Integrator (Supporting)
  • System Integration Tester (Supporting)
  • System Qualification Tester (Supporting)
  • Hardware Requirement Engineer (Supporting)
  • Hardware Architect (Supporting)
  • Hardware Design Engineer (Supporting)
  • Purchasing Manager (Informed)

  1. Quality Assurance Plan

main_description.name: Tailoring Guidelines
main_description.data: 1. Any section in this process can be tailored to add project-specific information or exclude any information which is out of scope.
main_description.bestPractices: None

main_description.name: Objective
main_description.data: The objective of this process is to analyze the stakeholder requirements to derive the system requirements which shall guide the design of the system.
main_description.bestPractices: The objective described is according to ASPICE Version 3.1 and VDA Automotive SPICE Guidelines Edition 2017. It is sufficient to achieve the required maturity up to ASPICE Level 3. Use the below table to extend the objective of the process if necessary.

main_description.name: Activity Diagram
main_description.data: The activity diagram of the process SYS.2 System Requirements Analysis is as shown below:

main_description.name: Activities
main_description.data: The following activities are performed in the scope of the process SYS.2 System Requirements Analysis:

subitem.name: Derive the System Requirements
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Considering that the functional contents are added over releases, the system requirements shall be iteratively updated.
  2. If the system is not functional safety or cybersecurity relevant, then such topics can be tailored to be out of scope.
  3. The tool to derive and store the system requirements can be changed based on customer requirements.
  4. It is not mandatory to derive the system requirements from the customer requirements. If the system is developed as a generic system, the platform requirements can be used.
subitem.tailoringExample:
• The System Requirements Specification is stored here: Link
  • As the system is non-safety critical, functional safety-related requirements are considered out of scope.
  • The system requirements are derived and stored in the tool DOORS.

subitem.name: Structure and Analysis of System Requirements
subitem.data: A detailed process will be added here.
subitem.bestPractices:
1. Insufficient memory or other resources in the controller during the project may indicate inappropriate analysis. Make sure that the impact on the operating environment such as microcontroller resources including memory, processor time, and peripheral resources are well studied and documented at the start of the project.
  2. The analysis of the feasibility of requirements may vary from using a simple checklist to building a prototype. An appropriate analysis method shall be used based on the type and context of the project
subitem.tailoringExample: The analysis results of the system requirements are recorded in the System Requirements Review & Analysis Protocol placed here: Link

subitem.name: Definition of verification criteria
subitem.data:
A detailed process will be added here.

The verification types are assigned to each of the derived software requirements as below
Requirement TypeVerification Type
Functional“Software Qualification Test” or “Review”
Non-FunctionalReview
subitem.bestPractices: 1. The verification criteria are described during the creation of software requirements.
subitem.tailoringExample: None

subitem.bestPractices: The Software Requirements Traceability Matrix is placed here: Link
subitem.tailoringExample: 1. Traceability tools such as Reqtify can be used to generate traceability reports between software requirements specification and system requirements/system architecture
